importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the previous major government shutdown, which lasted 35 days and was the longest in nearly 50 years.
The end date of the 2018 government shutdown, marking the conclusion of the longest shutdown in history.
The date of the latest update in the article, indicating ongoing government shutdown as of that point in time.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The duration of the 2018 shutdown, which lasted 35 days and was the longest in history, with an estimated $3 billion GDP loss.
The current full government shutdown, resulting from failure to pass any of the 12 appropriations bills required to fund federal operations.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown (December 22, 2018 â€“ January 25, 2019) was the longest in nearly 50 years, lasting 35 days.
The 2018 shutdown resulted in an estimated $3 billion loss in U.S. GDP according to the Congressional Budget Office.
An estimated 800,000 people were employed at shuttered federal agencies, with about 300,000 furloughed and 300,000 exempted from pay but required to report to work.
The current shutdown is a full government shutdown, meaning no appropriations bills have been passed to fund the federal government.
Since 1990, there have been six government shutdowns, and political polarization has made legislative compromise increasingly difficult.
Republican Speaker Mike Johnson oversees a narrow House majority, and the GOP lacks 60 Senate votes to end a filibuster, making negotiations difficult.
Federal agencies are not fully operational during a shutdown, and some services are halted while others continue under limited conditions.

namedEntities.name: United States federal government
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national government of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article discusses the current and past shutdowns of the U.S. federal government, highlighting the impact on operations and the economy.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nonpartisan office that provides economic analysis to Congress
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CBO estimated the $3 billion GDP loss during the 2018 shutdown, providing economic context to the impact of government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a key political figure in the current legislative stalemate, representing a narrow House majority and facing challenges in passing funding legislation.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A procedural rule in the U.S. Senate that allows for extended debate to block legislation
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Republican Party lacks the 60 votes needed to overcome a filibuster, which hinders passage of spending bills and contributes to the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A set of legislative bills that fund various federal agencies and services
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The failure to pass any of these bills is the direct cause of the current full government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article is published by CNN, which provides real-time updates and context on the ongoing government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: December 22, 2018
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A specific date marking the start of a government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This date marks the beginning of the longest government shutdown in nearly 50 years, which is referenced as a benchmark in the article.

namedEntities.name: January 25, 2019
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A specific date marking the end of the 2018 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This date signifies the conclusion of the longest shutdown in history, providing a clear timeline of past events.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. federal government remains in a full shutdown as of October 2025, following the failure to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. This marks a significant escalation compared to the 2018 shutdown, which lasted 35 days and was the longest in nearly 50 years, resulting in a $3 billion GDP loss and affecting approximately 800,000 federal employees. The current situation is exacerbated by political polarization, a narrow House majority led by Speaker Mike Johnson, and the lack of 60 Senate votes to break a filibuster. The article highlights how past and present shutdowns reflect deeper legislative gridlock, with the 2018 shutdown serving as a key historical benchmark due to its duration and economic impact.
title: The last government shutdown was the longest in nearly 50 years. Here are all the recent shutdowns in one chart
